title: High-throughput assessment of changes in the Caenorhabditis elegans gut microbiome
title_html: High-throughput assessment of changes in the Caenorhabditis elegans gut microbiome
article_citation: Dirksen P, Assié A, Zimmermann J, Zhang F, Tietje A, Marsh SA, Félix M, Shapira M, Kaleta C, Schulenburg H, Samuel BS, CeMbio - The Microbiome Resource. G3: Genes|Genomes|Genetics 10(9). doi: 10.1534/g3.120.401309

source.description:
Wash worms from bacterial lawns with M9 buffer +
Triton X to a sterilized 2 ml 96-well deep plate.
Use
M9+ Triton X to wash worms from a 12-well plate
Use
M9+ Triton X to wash worms from a 24-well plate

total with M9 +
Triton X using a multichannel pipette

Centrifuge deep well plate at
to pellet down worms, then remove liquid by using an aspirating manifold. Alternatively worms can be allowed to settle in the deep well plate by gravity without centrifugation to separate adults from progeny.

source.specifications: Aspirating manifold, allow liquid aspiration from 96 well plates

source.description: Repeat steps 2-3 5 times with M9 to further remove bacteria in liquid.

Bring the volume in each well down to
using the aspirating manifold.

Add
of
levamisole in 1X M9 + 0.01% Triton X to each well and allow the worms to paralyze for
. Confirm paralysis via microscopy before proceeding to the next step.

Add
of 4% bleach solution (2:1 Bleach:5M NaOH) in M9 to each well for

source.body: This will further eliminate bacteria in liquid and attached on worm cuticle.

source.description:
Repeat step 2-3 2 times with 1X M9 +
Triton X to remove bleach and levamisole.

Save
of supernatant from the last wash to use as a control to assess the background bacterial residual before host lysis.

Bring liquid volume in each well to
1X M9 +
Triton X, mix and transfer
of the mixture to a flat bottom 96 well plate (Costar 3370, Corning).
Take bright field images for each well for later analysis of worm population size, life stages, and individual length.

Aspirate remaining liquid volume down to
and add 1.0 mm sterilized garnet beads (Biospect) to each well (enough to cover well bottom).
Seal the plate with a sterile plastic mat and lyse worms in Mixer Mill (Restch) or TissueLyser at 25 Hz speed for 5 min.

Mix by pipetting and transfer
of cell lysate to a 96-well plate prepared with
1x PBS per well (1:10 dilution) and mix

Transfer
of the dilution from step 14 to
LB in 96 well flat bottom for liquid OD growth assay.

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description:
Fill a flat-bottom 96-well plate with
of sterile filtered PBS. Pipette
of the microbiome mixture used in the assay into four replicate wells in column 1 of the plate (e.g., A1, B1, C1, and D1). For controls, pipet
of LB in the remaining wells of column 1.

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description: Using a multichannel pipette, serially dilute the microbiome mixture (1:10) in columns 2-12 to create a dilution series for all wells of the plate. Change tips between each dilution/column.

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description:
From the serial dilution plate, plate
of each dilution onto a rectangular LB plate using a multichannel pipette. Incubate at optimal growth temperature overnight. Count colonies for each of the wells where possible.

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description:
Prepare a growth plate by filling each well of a flat bottom 96-well plate with
of LB. Transfer 20 μL from the serial dilution plate to the corresponding well of the growth plate. Incubate at the optimal temperature with intermittent shaking and monitor OD600 regularly (e.g., every 15-30 min) until growth is observed in all wells.

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description: Use a plotting software (Microsoft Excel, R or otherwise), to visualize growth curves by plotting OD600 reading vs time for each well on a single chart. Verify that the growth patterns are consistent between replicates and growth curves are ordered by the dilution factor.

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description:
Identify the range of OD600 values within the linear portion of the growth curves. Use the linear range identified and the following equation to calculate the optical density Threshold:

Threshold = \frac{(OD_{600max} - OD_{600min})}{2} + OD_{600min}

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description: Using the only data points where the OD600 readings for each well fall between the linear portion, calculate the Slope and Intercept for each well

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description:
To calculate the time at which each well reached the threshold (Y-axis of calibration curve), use the following equation for each well:
Time = \frac{(Threshold - Intercept)}{Slope}

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description: Plot CFU values collected in Step 19 vs.Time of Threshold crossing for each well, and calculate the R squared value and exponential trendline equation. Use the obtained equation to calculate CFU from the respective threshold time of each sample.

source.title: Calculate CFU based on liquid growth curve

source.description:
Determine colonization levels on a per animal basis for each sample using the following formula:

CFU / animal = \frac{(CFU * Dilution factor)}{number of animals}
Centrifuge the deep-well plate at 4000g for 10 mins to pellet worms and bacteria, then bring the remaining liquid volume down to
Freeze the lysate in -80 °C freezer overnight.DNA extraction and 16S rRNA PCR

Thaw the plate and add 0.1 mm sterile zirconia/silica beads (BioSpec products) to each well (enough to cover well bottom) and bead-beat in Mixer Mill (Restch) or TissueLyser for 5 mins to further lyse bacterial cells.

Add
of
proteinase K to each well.

In a ThermoCycler run a program as follow:

to desactivate the proteinase K

to pellet down cellular fractions.
Transfer
of supernatant to a clean 96 well PCR plate.
If using the plate again soon, place at

of 2x Taq Master Mix (1 tube)
of 515F primer
H2O

Add

Add
of reverse primer 806R to each well of the 96 well PCR plate.

Add
of the supernatant from the PCR plate prepared in step 23 as DNA template for the PCR.

The remaining supernatant can be frozen at
for storage.

Verify PCR amplification results with an agarose gel. Prepare a 1.5% agarose gel. Mix 2 µL of loading dye with 4 µL of PCR product per sample and load 5 µL in the gel along with 1 kb ladder.
Purify PCR product using commercial PCR purification kit.

Quantify the intensity of PCR product band from each library (gel or fluorometry), normalize PCR product amount by volume and pool libraries together with an equivalent amount of PCR product into a single tube.
Submit samples for multiplex sequencing along with sequencing primer

description: The gut microbiome is an important driver of host physiology and development. Altered abundance or membership of this microbe community can influence host health and disease progression, including the determination of host lifespan and healthspan. Here, we describe a robust pipeline to measure the microbiome abundance and composition in the C. elegans gut that can be applied to examine the role of the microbiome on host aging processes.
guidelines: This protocol starts once you have your nematodes of interest and want to know what type of bacteria, and how many are present in the worms digestive tract.
before_start:
Before starting the Colonization assay you should have the following:
  1. An egg prep of the desired worm strains
  2. Seeded NGM plate(s) with desired bacterial strain(s)
  3. Drop ~30 L1 worms on seeded plates and incubate at 20°C. Allow the worm to grow until desired age
materials_text:
STEP MATERIALS

Prepare all solutions using MilliQ water and store all reagents at room temperature unless otherwise noted.

1. Bacterial culture and maintenance
  1. LB Medium: Add 10 g bacto-tryptone to 900 mL water in 1 L glass autoclavable bottle (e.g., Pyrex), then add 5g bacto-yeast, 5 g NaCl and adjust pH to 7.0 using 5 M NaOH. For LB agar,add 15 g of agar, adjust volumeto 1000 mL and autoclave.
  2. Rectangular plates: Stamp out bacterial culture stock in 96 well plate format.
  3. Deep well plates: Grow bacterial culture in 96 well plate format (Axygen).
  5. 2. C. elegans culture and maintenance
  6. Nematode Growth Medium (NGM) Agar: Start with 975 mL water in 1 L glass autoclavable bottle (Pyrex, etc) , add 3.0 g NaCl, 2.5 g peptone, 17 g agar and autoclave with a magnetic stir bar. Cool the mixture down to 55°C on a heat plate preheated to 55°C and add the following while stirring it: 0.5 mL of 1 M CaCl2(sterile), 1 mL of 5 mg/mL cholesterol (dissolved in ethanol), 1 mL of 1 M MgSO4(sterile), 25 mL of 1 M potassium phosphate buffer, pH 6.0 (sterile), pour into petri dishes or multiple well plate using sterile technique.
  7. M9 buffer: Start with 700 mL water in 1 L glass autoclavable bottle (Pyrex, etc), add6 g Na2HPO4, 3 g KH2PO4, 5 g NaCl , 0.25 g MgSO4∙7H2O or 1 mL of 1 M MgSO4, add water to 1000 mL, and autoclave.
  8. Multiwell plates: 12 or 24 well plates with NGM agar for cultivation ofC. elegans.
  10. 3. Measurement of microbiome colonization levels
  11. M9-wash solution:Prepare 0.01% Triton X-100 solution in M9 buffer form 5% Triton X-100 stock solution in M9 buffer. Sterilize by filtration through 0.22 µm filter.
  12. Levamisole solution: Prepare 100 mM stock solution of levamisole in M9 buffer and dilute it to 10 mM to be used as working solution. Sterilize by filtration through 0.22 µm filter. Prepare fresh before use.
  13. Egg prep bleach solution: Mix 2 parts of Clorox bleach and 1 part of 5M NaOH. Prepare fresh before use.
  14. Wash bleach solution: Prepare a 4% Bleach solution in M9 buffer. Prepare fresh before use.
  15. Garnet beads (1.0 mm): for mechanical lysis of worms by bead-beating. Sterilize by autoclaving before use.
  16. Phosphate buffer saline(PBS;1X): pH 7.2, 0.22 µm filter sterilized.
  18. 4. Measurement of microbiome composition and diversity
  19. PCR primers
  20. Silica beads (0.1 mm): for mechanical lysis of bacterial cells by bead-beating prior to DNA isolation. Sterilize by autoclaving before use.
  21. 96-well PCR plates: for use in Proteinase K treatments during microbiome DNA extraction and PCR amplifications.
  22. PCR master mix
  23. Agarose gel electrophoresis supplies
  24. Low melt agarose powder
  25. TAE buffer (40 mM Tris-acetate, 1 mM EDTA)
  26. 1Kb ladder (NEB)
  27. Gel loading dye (NEB)
  28. PCR purification kit: Removes primers, nucleotides, enzymes and other impurities from PCR product before sequencing.
  30. 5. Equipment
  31. Multiple channel pipette: 12 channel pipettes (1000ul and 200ul) are commonly used in the assay to dispense liquid reagentsand transfer volumes between plates.
  32. Plate reader: for assessment of optical density (OD) in 96 well clear flat bottom plates.
  33. PCR thermocycler: for use in Proteinase K treatment during microbiome DNA extraction and generation of 16S rRNA gene amplicon libraries.
  34. Mixer mill: for use in lysis of animals and microbial cells by bead-beating (Retsch MM400).
  35. Microplate aspiration manifold: for use in rapid removal of supernatants during wash steps (VP1171A V&P scientific).

2. C. elegans culture and maintenance
  1. Nematode Growth Medium (NGM) Agar: Start with 975 mL water in 1 L glass autoclavable bottle (Pyrex, etc) , add 3.0 g NaCl, 2.5 g peptone, 17 g agar and autoclave with a magnetic stir bar. Cool the mixture down to 55°C on a heat plate preheated to 55°C and add the following while stirring it: 0.5 mL of 1 M CaCl2(sterile), 1 mL of 5 mg/mL cholesterol (dissolved in ethanol), 1 mL of 1 M MgSO4(sterile), 25 mL of 1 M potassium phosphate buffer, pH 6.0 (sterile), pour into petri dishes or multiple well plate using sterile technique.
  2. M9 buffer: Start with 700 mL water in 1 L glass autoclavable bottle (Pyrex, etc), add6 g Na2HPO4, 3 g KH2PO4, 5 g NaCl , 0.25 g MgSO4∙7H2O or 1 mL of 1 M MgSO4, add water to 1000 mL, and autoclave.
